original_pages.content:
For
My parents, who teach me.
Gretchen, who guides me.
Miles and Reese, who inspire me.

Introduction: The Greatest Show On Earth
 
1. No One’s Crazy
 
2. Luck & Risk
 
3. Never Enough
 
4. Confounding Compounding
 
5. Getting Wealthy vs. Staying Wealthy
 
6. Tails, You Win
 
7. Freedom
 
8. Man in the Car Paradox

9. Wealth is What You Don’t See
 
10. Save Money
 
11. Reasonable > Rational
 
12. Surprise!
 
13. Room for Error
 
14. You’ll Change
 
15. Nothing’s Free
 
16. You & Me
 
17. The Seduction of Pessimism
 
18. When You’ll Believe Anything
 
19. All Together Now
 
20. Confessions
 
Postscript: A Brief History of Why the U.S. Consumer Thinks the Way They Do
 
Endnotes
 
Acknowledgements
 
Publishing details

“A genius is the man who can do the average thing when
everyone else around him is losing his mind.”
—Napoleon
 
“The world is full of obvious things which nobody by any
chance ever observes.”
—Sherlock Holmes

Ispent my college years working as a valet at a nice hotel in Los Angeles.
One frequent guest was a technology executive. He was a genius, having designed and
patented a key component in Wi-Fi routers in his 20s. He had started and sold several
companies. He was wildly successful.
He also had a relationship with money I’d describe as a mix of insecurity and childish
stupidity.
He carried a stack of hundred dollar bills several inches thick. He showed it to everyone
who wanted to see it and many who didn’t. He bragged openly and loudly about his wealth,
often while drunk and always apropos of nothing.
One day he handed one of my colleagues several thousand dollars of cash and said, “Go to
the jewelry store down the street and get me a few $1,000 gold coins.”
An hour later, gold coins in hand, the tech executive and his buddies gathered around by a
dock overlooking the Paciﬁc Ocean. They then proceeded to throw the coins into the sea,
skipping them like rocks, cackling as they argued whose went furthest. Just for fun.
Days later he shattered a lamp in the hotel’s restaurant. A manager told him it was a $500
lamp and he’d have to replace it.
“You want ﬁve hundred dollars?” the executive asked incredulously, while pulling a brick of
cash from his pocket and handing it to the manager. “Here’s ﬁve thousand dollars. Now get
out of my face. And don’t ever insult me like that again.”
You may wonder how long this behavior could last, and the answer was “not long.” I learned
years later that he went broke.
The premise of this book is that doing well with money has a little to do with how smart you
are and a lot to do with how you behave. And behavior is hard to teach, even to really smart
people.

A genius who loses control of their emotions can be a ﬁnancial disaster. The opposite is also
true. Ordinary folks with no ﬁnancial education can be wealthy if they have a handful of
behavioral skills that have nothing to do with formal measures of intelligence.
 
 
My favorite Wikipedia entry begins: “Ronald James Read was an American philanthropist,
investor, janitor, and gas station attendant.”
Ronald Read was born in rural Vermont. He was the ﬁrst person in his family to graduate
high school, made all the more impressive by the fact that he hitchhiked to campus each
day.
For those who knew Ronald Read, there wasn’t much else worth mentioning. His life was
about as low key as they come.
Read ﬁxed cars at a gas station for 25 years and swept ﬂoors at JCPenney for 17 years. He
bought a two-bedroom house for $12,000 at age 38 and lived there for the rest of his life.
He was widowed at age 50 and never remarried. A friend recalled that his main hobby was
chopping ﬁrewood.
Read died in 2014, age 92. Which is when the humble rural janitor made international
headlines.
2,813,503 Americans died in 2014. Fewer than 4,000 of them had a net worth of over $8
million when they passed away. Ronald Read was one of them.
In his will the former janitor left $2 million to his stepkids and more than $6 million to his
local hospital and library.
Those who knew Read were baﬄed. Where did he get all that money?
It turned out there was no secret. There was no lottery win and no inheritance. Read saved
what little he could and invested it in blue chip stocks. Then he waited, for decades on end,
as tiny savings compounded into more than $8 million.
That’s it. From janitor to philanthropist.
A few months before Ronald Read died, another man named Richard was in the news.
Richard Fuscone was everything Ronald Read was not. A Harvard-educated Merrill Lynch
executive with an MBA, Fuscone had such a successful career in ﬁnance that he retired in
his 40s to become a philanthropist. Former Merrill CEO David Komansky praised Fuscone’s
“business savvy, leadership skills, sound judgment and personal integrity.”¹ Crain’s
business magazine once included him in a “40 under 40” list of successful businesspeople.²
But then—like the gold-coin-skipping tech executive—everything fell apart.
In the mid-2000s Fuscone borrowed heavily to expand an 18,000-square foot home in
Greenwich, Connecticut that had 11 bathrooms, two elevators, two pools, seven garages,
and cost more than $90,000 a month to maintain.
Then the 2008 ﬁnancial crisis hit.
The crisis hurt virtually everyone’s ﬁnances. It apparently turned Fuscone’s into dust. High
debt and illiquid assets left him bankrupt. “I currently have no income,” he allegedly told a

bankruptcy judge in 2008.
First his Palm Beach house was foreclosed.
In 2014 it was the Greenwich mansion’s turn.
Five months before Ronald Read left his fortune to charity, Richard Fuscone’s home—where
guests recalled the “thrill of dining and dancing atop a see-through covering on the home’s
indoor swimming pool”—was sold in a foreclosure auction for 75% less than an insurance
company ﬁgured it was worth.³
Ronald Read was patient; Richard Fuscone was greedy. That’s all it took to eclipse the
massive education and experience gap between the two.
The lesson here is not to be more like Ronald and less like Richard—though that’s not bad
advice.
The fascinating thing about these stories is how unique they are to ﬁnance.
In what other industry does someone with no college degree, no training, no background,
no formal experience, and no connections massively outperform someone with the best
education, the best training, and the best connections?
I struggle to think of any.
It is impossible to think of a story about Ronald Read performing a heart transplant better
than a Harvard-trained surgeon. Or designing a skyscraper superior to the best-trained
architects. There will never be a story of a janitor outperforming the world’s top nuclear
engineers.
But these stories do happen in investing.
The fact that Ronald Read can coexist with Richard Fuscone has two explanations. One,
ﬁnancial outcomes are driven by luck, independent of intelligence and eﬀort. That’s true to
some extent, and this book will discuss it in further detail. Or, two (and I think more
common), that ﬁnancial success is not a hard science. It’s a soft skill, where how you
behave is more important than what you know.
I call this soft skill the psychology of money. The aim of this book is to use short stories to
convince you that soft skills are more important than the technical side of money. I’ll do this
in a way that will help everyone—from Read to Fuscone and everyone in between—make
better ﬁnancial decisions.
These soft skills are, I’ve come to realize, greatly underappreciated.
Finance is overwhelmingly taught as a math-based ﬁeld, where you put data into a formula
and the formula tells you what to do, and it’s assumed that you’ll just go do it.
This is true in personal ﬁnance, where you’re told to have a six-month emergency fund and
save 10% of your salary.
It’s true in investing, where we know the exact historical correlations between interest rates
and valuations.
And it’s true in corporate ﬁnance, where CFOs can measure the precise cost of capital.

paragraphs.title: Dedication from the Author
paragraphs.content: For my parents, who teach me. Gretchen, who guides me. Miles and Reese, who inspire me. The introduction of 'The Greatest Show On Earth' sets the stage for a profound exploration of human behavior and finance. Each chapter title, such as 'No One’s Crazy,' 'Luck & Risk,' and 'Never Enough,' hints at a journey through unique perspectives on wealth, life, and decision-making. Through titles like 'Confounding Compounding' and 'Getting Wealthy vs. Staying Wealthy,' the author invites us to consider the complexity and long-term vision often required in financial endeavors.

paragraphs.title: Exploring Paradoxes and Unexpected Outcomes of Life
paragraphs.content: Chapters like 'Tails, You Win,' 'Freedom,' and 'Man in the Car Paradox' promise an examination of the unexpected outcomes and paradoxes that challenge conventional wisdom, all tied together under the metaphorical 'greatest show on earth' that is life.

paragraphs.title: The Fall of the Tech Genius
paragraphs.content: In my college years working as a valet at a Los Angeles hotel, I encountered a frequent guest, a technology executive who epitomized a complex relationship with money. Despite his brilliance, having designed a key Wi-Fi router component and founded successful companies, his childish display of wealth ultimately led to his financial ruin. This sets the stage for the book's premise: success with money is less about intelligence and more about behavior, which even the smartest can struggle to master. A genius uncontrolled by emotions can become a financial mess, while an ordinary person with basic behavioral skills can build wealth, as exemplified by Ronald Read, a humble janitor who left an $8 million fortune upon his death.

paragraphs.title: The Unique Dynamics of Finance
paragraphs.content: His story is contrasted with Richard Fuscone, a Harvard-educated former Merrill Lynch executive who went bankrupt due to over-leveraging despite his credentials. These narratives highlight the unique nature of finance, where financial success relies more on soft skills and behavior than formal education, which is unlike any other field. The book delves into the psychology of money to demonstrate the significance of these soft skills in financial decision-making, often overlooked in favor of math-based approaches. While health science has advanced through scientific precision, finance remains a field governed by human behavior and emotions, affecting everyone and often misunderstood.

paragraphs.title: Exploring the Psychology of Money
paragraphs.content: Our understanding of money could benefit from considering historical patterns of greed and optimism. This book comprises twenty chapters that explore key aspects of financial behavior, each as an independent and insightful exploration into the psychology of money, crafted to ensure readers grasp the core concepts without overdrawn explanations.

paragraphs.title: Different Money Experiences, Different Lessons
paragraphs.content: Let me tell you about a problem. People do some crazy things with money, but no one is crazy. Diverse generations, raised by different parents with varying income levels, come from distinct parts of the world, experiencing different economies and levels of luck. These differences shape unique life lessons. What you've experienced is often more compelling than second-hand information. Hence, views on money vary significantly among individuals. The person who grew up in poverty views risk differently than the child of a wealthy banker. An investor who suffered a stock market crash can’t relate to someone who flourished during a boom. This diversity of experience shapes our understanding of financial matters.

paragraphs.title: Perception Shapes Financial Views
paragraphs.content: Understanding these differing perspectives is crucial. Personal experiences with money may cover a minuscule fraction of global financial history, yet they represent the bulk of our worldview. This diversity explains why equally intelligent people can disagree about saving, investing, and risk. JFK's lack of firsthand experience with the Great Depression was questioned during his presidential campaign. Our interpretations of financial crises stem from personal experiences. The emotional scars of those who suffered directly through events like the Great Depression can't be matched by those merely reading about it. As Michael Batnick says, 'some lessons have to be experienced before they can be understood.'

paragraphs.title: Generational Influence on Financial Risk
paragraphs.content: In 2006, economists Ulrike Malmendier and Stefan Nagel found that people's financial decisions are heavily influenced by their generational experiences. Our willingness to take financial risks is shaped by personal history rather than intelligence or education. The difference in investment habits between individuals can be attributed to the luck of when and where they were born. The disparities in how people experience money are significant, even among similar individuals. For someone born in 1970, the S&P 500 increased tenfold during their formative years, while someone born in 1950 saw no inflation-adjusted growth. Such differences shape divergent views on the stock market.

paragraphs.title: Historical and Social Contexts Shape Financial Perspectives
paragraphs.content: America's economic indicators in 2009 varied drastically across social and ethnic groups. Past experiences, such as Japan's and Germany’s post-war recoveries or the U.S. economic boom during WWII, form diverse perspectives on money. Each group's view on money stemmed from their unique experiences, influencing how they interpreted and responded to financial information. A stark illustration of diversified perspectives is seen in lottery ticket purchases, predominantly by low-income individuals seeking an escape from financial constraints. Understanding the narrative behind such decisions offers insight into the perceived rationality of seemingly irrational financial behaviors.

paragraphs.title: The Personal and New Age of Money Decisions
paragraphs.content: Money decisions aren't just about numbers; they're personal. They involve ego, past experiences, and individual views. Furthermore, topics like retirement are relatively new. Only two generations ago, most Americans worked until death. This shows how recent saving and investing concepts are in financial decision-making.

paragraphs.title: Luck and Risk: Forces Beyond Control
paragraphs.content: Luck and risk are intertwined, both highlighting how outcomes are often governed by external factors rather than solely by individual effort. Scott Galloway aptly notes, 'Nothing is as good or as bad as it seems,' underscoring the unpredictable role these forces play in shaping success. Bill Gates exemplifies incredible fortune, attending Lakeside School—a rare educational institution with a computer in 1968, an uncommon advantage for a 13-year-old. Gates, alongside Paul Allen, immersed themselves in computing, laying the foundation for Microsoft's creation.

paragraphs.title: Lakeside's Influence: An Acknowledged Catalyst
paragraphs.content: Out of millions of high-school-age students globally, Gates was among the fortunate few at Lakeside, illustrating luck's pivotal role in his journey. Gates himself later acknowledged, 'If there had been no Lakeside, there would have been no Microsoft.' However, Gates' peer Kent Evans experienced the harsh sibling of luck: risk. Equally talented and ambitious, Kent could have co-founded Microsoft, but his life was tragically cut short in a mountaineering accident—a stark reminder of how risk can abruptly alter life's trajectory.

paragraphs.title: Dual Forces: Success and Hindrance
paragraphs.content: This dual narrative reveals how similar forces can propel one towards success while hindering another. The truth is, our actions dictate only a fraction of our outcomes; the world is far too complex for complete control. Noteworthy is economist Robert Shiller's reflection on the enigmatic influence of luck in investment success, a sentiment echoed in societal reluctance to fully attribute success to chance. Nonetheless, research like Bhashkar Mazumder's demonstrates income likeness in siblings, hinting at systemic factors beyond merit.

paragraphs.title: Misinterpretations: Complexity in Success and Failure
paragraphs.content: The tendency to overlook or misinterpret these influences leads to skewed perceptions of failure and success. An individual's downfall is often attributed to poor choices, yet in truth, systemic complexity deeply muddies the waters of cause and effect. Cultural narratives frequently celebrate successful individuals without acknowledging the role of risk and luck, leading to misconceptions about repeatable success strategies. This highlights a cognitive bias in evaluating achievements—while we aim to replicate what seemingly works, without acknowledging luck, these strategies may not guarantee similar outcomes.

paragraphs.title: 'Enough': The Essence of Contentment
paragraphs.content: John Bogle, the Vanguard founder, recounted an insightful story about money. At a billionaire's party, Kurt Vonnegut told Joseph Heller that their host, a hedge fund manager, earned more in a day than Heller did from his novel 'Catch-22'. Heller calmly replied, 'Yes, but I have something he will never have… enough.' This simplicity of 'enough' highlighted a striking truth: in society, especially among the wealthy, there's often no limit to what constitutes enough.

paragraphs.title: The Costs of Insatiable Greed
paragraphs.content: The dangers of not knowing what 'enough' really means are exemplified by the likes of Rajat Gupta and Bernie Madoff. Gupta, from a humble beginning in Kolkata, rose to become the prestigious CEO of McKinsey, amassing wealth and influence. Yet he yearned for more—billionaire status. This drove him to insider trading, ultimately leading to his fall from grace. Similarly, Madoff, before his Ponzi scheme, was a legitimate and successful market maker. Nevertheless, the insatiable desire for more led him to fraud.

paragraphs.title: The Costs of Insatiable Greed
paragraphs.content: Both men had vast wealth, power, and freedom, yet the lack of 'enough' led them astray. Warren Buffett once remarked on such irrational behavior: 'To make money they didn't have and didn't need, they risked what they did have and did need.' This highlights how the inability to stop the moving goalpost of financial success leads to ruin. Social comparison only exacerbates this, as illustrated by the disparity in earnings across different fields.

paragraphs.title: Comparative Trap: The Cycle of Envy
paragraphs.content: The perpetual chase for more, driven by envy, leads to a cycle where individuals never truly win unless they realize the power of having 'enough'. Knowing 'enough' isn't conservatism but recognizing the destructive potential of the endless pursuit of more, akin to knowing one's limit with food before it ends in regret. There are invaluable facets like reputation that should never be risked regardless of the gain, as learned by Gupta post-prison, 'Don't get too attached to anything—your reputation, your accomplishments or any of it.'
